body: We went to the train station to get our QR rail passes activated. The place to do this wasn’t that easy to find.

We walked to the Meiji shrine. It’s much larger than I imagined and built within a forest. Just after we arrived at the shrine a wedding procession was in progress.

There was a long gravel road that goes through the forest with the shrine complex in the centre. There was one worker using a broom to sweep all the leaves off the entire road. He would sweep the leaves into little piles and another worker put them into a bag. That must take all day and every day to do that!
We donated 500¥ each and walked around the gardens below then shrine. They would look beautiful in the spring with all the flowers blooming, but it was still impressive with the autumn leaves.
We had to queue for 10 minutes just to see the small stream of clear water coming up out of the ground.

There was a food stall off the main road selling roasted rice balls on a stick called ‘Dango’ for 350¥. There were three rice cakes per stick so it was the right number for sharing with Katherine and Anita.
The Line Friends Store selling BT21 gear was nearby. The store was three stories high and absolutely packed with people. Katherine bought some gifts for her friends at home.

We failed in our attempt to buy train tickets. I later learned that Suica cards are used like our cards at home and you don’t need to buy tickets with them.

Later I also discovered that
We arrived at the 4th station to pouring rain and driving cold winds. Visibility was very low so absolutely no chance of seeing the huge mountain we were on!
After returning from the mountain we were taken to a resort hotel for lunch. It was nice to be in a warm room to dry off in.
We had a short stay on the lake at Hakone. Due to the really bad weather the boat cruise was cancelled.

Some of the passengers were catching the Shinkansen back to Tokyo - a 30min trip from there. Since we would have needed to transfer to another local train to get back to Shinjuku we decided to stay with the coach.
After yesterday’s disaster of a day, today was sunny and Mt Fuji was clearly visible from the train.
The station to get off when going to Studio Gibli.
We found a bakery near the station and stocked up with supplies for the day.
By sheer good fortune, we saw the Emperor of Japan and his wife’s motorcade drive past as we walked to the Castle Ruins
I bought a hot milk coffee in a can.
It is a huge station but seemed to be easier to navigate than the Shinjuku station.
We order Yakitori and rice. Katherine had a huge bowl of Ramen.
We found the Tokyo Station Character Street. I tried to find a model toy of the Nissan LEAF but they only had the Gen 2 version.
After our shopping adventure in Tokyo, we caught the JR RAPID train back to Shinjuku. It was only normally crowded tonight but we still had to stand up for the short ride.
I’m not sure this is the name of the place, but it was nine floors of electrical and electronic goods!

I woke up with a sore throat this morning. It will probably get worse over the coming days. I don’t know if I feel terrible today from climbing the mountain yesterday, or because I’m getting sick again? Time will tell.
We go back to the tourist centre to reserve our Shinkansen tickets for tomorrow’s trip down to Kyoto.
We ride the train to Mitaka. We are going to the Gibli museum

We arrive at the museum after a 1.4 km walk up a leaf covered lane. A small stream flows along side the lane.

The studio is amazing and the building is a high-quality construction meant to look like something from the 1800’s - at least on the inside. Unfortunately I couldn’t take any photos inside the museum.

We bought hotdogs, chips and a soup at the museum cafe.
After leaving the museum, we walk though a park and decide to go to the local zoo. Tourists get a 20% discount so the three of us get in for just under ¥1000.
The Pokémon Mega Store is located here.
I saw a very unusual bus walking back to the hotel. It had lots of wheels like a tank with tracks and was fully electric.
Catching train to Shinagawa to transfer to the Shinkansen to Kyoto.

There was a problem with the train so it stopped one station short of our destination. It was easy enough to catch the next one waiting on the same platform.

We had to help some tourists who didn’t understand what was happening.
The were many shops selling bento boxes of all kinds at the station. We bought something to eat for lunch on the train.
I finally managed to get some shots of Mt Fuji from the train window as we passed through the region.
We arrived at Kyoto station in just 2.5 hours.
We went upstairs and had dinner at a restaurant that had Kobe Beef on the menu. I had to try some despite the expense.
Due to the close proximity of the restaurant to the hotel, Arc is getting confused.
After leaving the hotel we went to a chemist to by the equivalent of Codral. This is the version with real ephedrine and codeine.

The aquarium was only a short walk from the station. The feature animal there was the giant salamander. They also had all the usual things like dolphins, seals, and penguins. Their viewing aquarium was fairly small but effectively done. I’ve never seen an aquarium with a school of small fish that form a twisting cloud.

It’s also the first time I’ve seen little spotted garden eels.
Bought a HDMI cable for the iPad to connect it to the TV. Then I discovered that Disney+ is not available in Japan yet! Maybe I can use a proxy from Sydney?
Went on a local train to Inari to see the famous temple with the thousands of orange gates leading up the mountain.
The temple did not disappoint although it seems to cater to tourists more than most. I guess that’s the price of popularity.

Anita always seems to find a mountain to climb and this was a tough one despite or maybe because of all the steps. I was sick as well which didn’t help although my heart rate seemed relatively low for the effort.

I was surprised at how extensive the gate construction has gone. There must be thousands of them in all sizes over the mountain.

Many Japanese people come up here to prey for their ancestors, so we will chalk this up as another reason Japanese people are rarely overweight.
We waited for sunset because it’s apparently the best time to take photos and they are correct. It was painfully cold however.
We found a nearby coin laundry and washed most of our dirty clothes.
I think this is where there was a horse stable to the side of the path with a statue of a horse in it. This was also a good spot to take pictures of the main shrine.
Wasted valuable time finding a toilet. There was one at the next destination anyway!
1st cable car ride up the mountain.
Second cable car. We were packed in like the subway.
At the summit finally.
We caught the orange route bus to the castle stop. These buses accept JR passes.
The castle is closed for the next two days for renovations.
We left the castle grounds via another bridge over the moat. There were a huge number of large Koi swimming near the bridge. Fish feeding pellets were available so Katherine obliged.
There was a class of school students in front of the monument performing a ceremony.

The images and stories this place contains are very upsetting and is a strong argument against the use of such destructive nuclear weapons. Knowing that the latest nuclear warheads are hundreds of times more destructive is further proof the world is insane.
We checked out of the hotel late. I’ll miss the executive club lounge with the free coffee and other things to eat.

We wander around the station looking for something to eat in the train. I eventually settle for sushi. They were huge with almost a small one inside the main roll.

Katherine had fried chicken
We had to transfer to a second Shinkansen train to go back to Tokyo.
Back at Tokyo Station we decide to go straight back to Shinjuku on a local JR train.
Even though it was supposed to be after peak hour the train was still packed like sardines for the last part of the journey. More people kept getting on than those getting off.

Back at the same hotel but in room 1962 on the other side this time.

We went to our favourite store inside the hotel and bought dinner and breakfast. They asked if I wanted to have my bento meal heated? Yes, and that made my night.
There were a few monkeys around the pool but none ever jumped in. It wasn’t cold enough.
Went inside the cafe for chips and a cup of coffee.
We had about 45 minutes to wait for the train, so we looked around. Nagano is an Apple growing region, so there were a few shops selling Apple pies.
We caught a JR train to Yokohama station
We decided to go to the Nissan Headquarters first as it was close to the station.
Anita wanted something sweet, so we stopped at a bakery / cafe to have coffee and a cake
From the bakery it was a short walk along a raised walkway to the entrance of Nissan Headquarters.
The gallery was fairly impressive with the entire range of Nissan’s new cars as well as some of the notable older ones.
So now it was on to the Cup Noodles Museum. Anita wanted to catch the ferry there.
It wasn’t far for the ferry, and it was good to be on the water. I was impressed by the size of the harbour.

The museum was on multiple levels. One floor was dedicated to one example of every cup and sachel sold.

Another floor was set up for each major country the cup noodles is sold in where you could buy and sample the noodles. We ordered the Italian noodles and they were quite good.

Katherine had a ticket to the floor where she made a custom cup. She had it for breakfast the following morning.
The Nissan Headquarters was on the way back to the station so we returned to buy a golf shirt, a coffee mug, key ring, and Leaf key cover.
Outside I finally saw a red Gen 1 leaf charging on the rapid charger.
We caught the train from Yokohama back to Tokyo and Character Street where Katherine bought more things from the Pokémon store.

This was an opportunity to stop at Shibuya to see the famous crossing and walk around the district. We found a place to eat on the eighth floor of the building. It specialised in Italian food, so this was the second time I had Italian style noodles.
Checked out at 11:00am and then checked our luggage with the bell hop so we could walk around for a few hours.
We reserve our seats on the Narita express all the way over the other side of the station

After we reserved our seats on the Narita Express, Anita wanted to buy some things for everyone at home, so we went to the department store above the station.

Up there we found a place to eat. It had a great view of the city as it was located on the 12th floor. I ordered spaghetti again. That’s three times in two days if I count the cup noodles version at the museum.
Picked up our luggage from the hotel
We are 20 minutes early at the platform, but the train was already there. It’s a very modern looking train.
It didn’t go any faster than the local trains averaging 68kms/hr
Anita and Katherine did more shopping at the airport. It would be possible to get most things there
We said that we had been in wilderness areas but they weren’t too concerned.
The WRX was covered in dust after sitting for two weeks in the airport carpark so I drove to the car wash first
Something went wrong with the location. This should be home not the carwash.
Washed the LEAF this time which was also covered in dust from sitting in the garage for two weeks. The car lost 5% of charge over the two weeks.
Went for a drive to Cleveland and back. It was extremely windy there and something hit the car while I was parked. I think it was something from a nearby pine tree?

Went to see mum with Katherine. We gave her gifts from Japan and showed here photos and videos of the trip.

I do t remember seeing the oxygen concentrator there.
Picked up some additional double adaptors for the bedroom chargers and for holidays. Also bought a brush for cleaning mums wheelchair.
We had dinner there and I eventually won $50.
Bought a lightning to audio adaptor
WRX - 32.24L of Vortex98 at $1.779/L
We went to Rochedale to buy special ingredients for Katherine’s cake for tomorrow’s Christmas celebrations at Erika’s  retirement village.
The we went to Garden City to buy presents for everybody. Anita wanted a new purse. I ended up buying a Lenovo version of a Google Assistant Clock.
Went to Arcare to attach an oximeter because I thought they had removed it, but it was there! So I still attached the oximeter to see if the oxygen works.
I took what I thought would be the slow way home and it was quicker despite all the traffic lights!

Picked up the oximeter. I seem to have forgotten to turn it on at the wall, so there is only 4 hours of data. ☹️

From the fours hours the days were stable with no evidence of a cheyne-stokes breathing pattern.
Having a family birthday party at the retirement village.
Walked back to grannies unit with Mudite and Rogers wife who hadn’t been there before.
We walked back to the community centre through the nursing home.

The leafs SOH was dropping with every trip, so I drove over to Eat Street to rapid charge it to see if that would do something.

While I was there I was lucky to meet a young fellow in a Tesla Model 3 who was a software engineer at Tritium!
I’ll keep driving the LEAF to work while my left leg is recovering and the parking pressure is off due to Xmas holidays.
Lunch on the green. It was heavily overcast today, otherwise it would have been too hot to sit there.
Meeting with Frank at Mater IT.
Had the two steaks for the price of one deal. Tonight I won $80.
Left work early. Leanne Gauld came in and said to go home!
Trip to Mc Donald’s to buy dinner.

Went for a drive to burn off 20% charge since we are not going anywhere today. I had charged it to 100% in anticipation of a driving day, but Anita is doing washing and wasn’t planning to go anywhere until this evening.
8 min, 5.9 kWh
6 mins, 4 kWh. The battery temperature was almost 41 degrees.
I came back to the charger to top up to 91% to make it possible to get home later without needing to recharge anywhere.
Parked the car. I drove past the EV charging bays and one of the bays had been ICE’d by a Land Rover Sport. We were only parking at the shopping centre and then going into Surfers.
Had a coffee and cheese cake.
Ordered the beef Korean BBQ. Maybe a bit too much meat even for the three of us.
The battery still had about 72% charge, so is enough to drive home and still have 30% left.
Picked up Katherine’s friend. They are all going to the movies.
I bought a 10W induction charger for the iPhone 11 Pro.
I discovered I had a $100 Apple voucher so I used it to help buy a DJI stabiliser. The other one blocks the wide-angle lens on the iPhone 11 Pro.

Went to the Cafe to apologise and pay for a coffee that I forgot to pay for a few weeks ago. The owner was right there and she said don’t worry about it. Merry Christmas!

And then as I was leaving our old neighbour Jason tapped me on the shoulder and we talked for a while. His daughter is now a kindergarten teacher and one of her children is starting in Prep in 2020. 

Jason sold up his investment properties and bought a house in Carindale just a few streets away from the shopping centre. The older son is married now.
Back to the car. It had been on the charger for 1:59 hrs:min which is approx 30 kms worth of free charge.
Katherine wanted to do some shopping so I waited at the Shingle Inn for a bit.
Bacon and eggs on toast and a cup of tea
Katherine is looking for a specific adidas shoe, but no one has them in stock.
Having coffee
Katherine wants a specific sand shoe from Adidas and Myers is out of stock
Getting battery replaced in Katherine’s watch. $22.00 and 15 minutes
Walking around looking in other shoe stores. There are a lot of them!
Picking up Erica from playing cards at the Latvian Hall.
Ordered KFC for dinner - two chicken tender packs and a favourites pack.

Dropped Katherine off and got straight in for a haircut.

Somewhere in here lunch at Sushi Edo has gone missing? I had their half udon. The place was busy.

I bought some odds and ends at Harvey Norman. More black ink for the Epson printer; two WiFi power points that were on special and can be controlled by Google Home and Amazon Alexa; a USB-C to micro-USB adaptor; a USB 3 thumb drive and a really cheap but slim 5000 mWh battery with a digital charge readout.
Anita wanted bread and milk from Coles.
Picked up Katherine from Garden City.
We’re here for dinner - steaks! We ordered the scotch fillets at $30 each. Mine was terrible! It was stringy and tough. I was exhausted trying to chew it.
We took Katherine home and then went to the Southside Club. I initially had a terrible time but eventually won enough back to avert a disaster. I ended up losing $60
Forester - 41.15L of Vortex98 at $1.609/L
I went to see if this bike repair company still existed and was open. They are in an industrial area which was all closed for the Christmas - New Year period.
This place was also closed over Xmas and New Year
Anita got home and wanted to leave straight away for Garden City.
We had some time to kill so had tea and coffee at Devons I think
We ordered hot dogs and went in to see “Star Wars - the last Skywalker”
